claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination is proposed to increase tumor immunogenicity and improve anti-PD-L1 responses by expanding antigen presentation on MHC-I.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: The report notes that some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems, so effects may not be uniform across tumors.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination induces higher type I interferon activity in tumors than comparator conditions in the mouse experiments.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: The table summarizes these values, and the report does not provide additional design details for each numerical comparison in this extract.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is necessary for the sensitization benefit in preclinical settings, because anti-IFNAR1 blockade abolished the benefit.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: This is a mechanistic inference from preclinical perturbation controls and cannot by itself prove causality in patients.

claims.claim: In the retrospective human cohort, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival under ICI treatment compared with no prior vaccination.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: This analysis is retrospective with heterogeneous tumor types and variable vaccination timing, so unmeasured confounding may influence outcomes.
